SafetyInspectionBy: City of Vernon Health & Environmental Control

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The building at 3425 East Vernon Avenue, Vernon, California is leased by CLW Foods.  The property management company, G&K Management, utilizes the services of a professional refrigeration contractor, Mericle Mechanical to maintain and operate the ammonia refrigeration systems.  Regular checks are made of the systems to ensure it is functioning properly and in good repair.

The facility has an emergency evacuation plan that includes ammonia leaks.  If an ammonia leak or an alarm indicating an ammonia leak is observed by facility personnel, the decision to evacuate the building is made by management.  Professional emergency responders and the facility's professional refrigeration service firm are called to assist with the ammonia leak.  If an ammonia leak exceeds 25 parts per million in the engine rooms, an audible/visual alarm is triggered.  At 250 ppm all refrigeration equipment in the engine rooms is de-energized.

The management at G&K Management and CLW Foods are committed to safety.  The emergency action plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The facility is located at 3425 East Vernon Avenue in Vernon, California, which is approximately 2.1 miles west of Interstate 710 and 1.7 miles southeast of the Interstate 5 - Interstate 10 - Highway 60 interchange. The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban.  The facility has four ammonia refrigeration systems on site.  The facility utilizes two independent ammonia refrigeration systems (BK West Medium Low Temp System and BK West Frigo System) for dock operations, process equipment, and cold storage.  The remaining two systems (CKE York System and CKE Frigo System) have been pumped down and are n

g the possibility of any ammonia releases. 

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the systems are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to a household refrigerator.  Any leaks are noted during daily operation by plant personnel and repaired immediately.

Level indicators are located on vessels maintaining a liquid level. Pressure indicators are located throughout the process. The level and pressure indicators allow operators to monitor system operations and to determine potential adverse situations in the event of deviations from standard or acceptable operating conditions. Regular system inspections also permit operators to monitor operations.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material in the past five years (November 2007 to November 2012).  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or near misses that warranted an internal incident investigation.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has an emergency evacuation plan that includes ammonia leaks.  If an ammonia leak or an alarm indicating an ammonia leak is observed by facility personnel, the decision to evacuate the building is made by management.  The facility's professional refrigeration service firm, Mericle Mechanical, is called to assist with the ammonia leak.  The refrigeration contractor can be reached at (714) 404-9489.  

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The initial Hazard Review, performed on January 20 - 21, 2010 generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the facility.  The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance relat

ot of service.

Each refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid).  The majority of the refrigeration equipment is located inside the engine rooms.  Each system is a closed loop refrigeration system similar to a residential refrigerator.  There are no emissions or planned releases of ammonia.

The maximum intended inventory of ammonia for the two operating systems is as follows:

BK West Frigo System - 8,000 lbs.
BK West Medium/Low Temp System - 3,350 lbs.

Note: The BK West Frigo and the BK West Medium/Low Temp Systems are located in the same engine room on the west side of the facility.  The systems are co-located and are thus considered as one process.  The CKE Frigo and CKE York systems are pumped down but are still onsite.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The facility utilizes ammonia leak detectors that are located in the engine rooms and the loading dock and have the capability of: 1) triggering an audible/visual alarm, and 2) disabling electrical equipment in the engine room.  

Each pressure vessel is equipped with pressure relief valves that automatically engage to vent excess pressure to protect the integrity of the vessel.  All pressure relief valves in the BK West refrigeration systems feed into a common header that vents into a diffusion tank.   

The refrigeration systems were designed in accordance with the codes applicable at the time of installation including the Uniform Mechanical Code, the Uniform Fire Code, ANSI/ASHRAE, and local City of Vernon building and electrical codes.

In the event of a power failure, ammonia operations would automatically shut down (solenoid valves close, compressors shut down, condenser fans and water pumps shut down, spiral freezers shut down, etc.), thereby limitin

ed tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  Also, G&K Management is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:

1.	Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2.	Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3.	Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4.	Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
